items.title: [a11y]: v11 Tooltip/IconButton behavior for Pagination
Design for pagination number input
items.body:
### Summary
A large number of total items in the pagination select causes problems described in https://github.com/carbon-design-system/carbon/issues/5129 and https://github.com/carbon-design-system/carbon/issues/4365

Without alternative designs, a proposed workaround is to remove the ability to select a page or limit the height of the select window https://github.com/carbon-design-system/carbon/pull/5485 

### Desired UX and success metrics
Create designs that allow the user to navigate to a specific page without incrementally clicking the forward and back pagination nav arrow.

### Considerations:
- [ ] Error message
- [ ] Always require a value
- [ ] The behavior when the number entered is greater than the number of pages (Reset to the highest page?)
- [ ] What other components have this type of input inside a toolbar or component? What needs to be established for this type of pattern? 

### Exploration
Number input specs that are similar to the mobile ipnut component.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19270502/75998210-18278480-5ec6-11ea-82cd-2654701a228f.png)

items.title: Sorted and Searchable DataTable with Pagination from backend
items.body:
<!--

Hi there! üëã Hope everything is going okay using projects from the Carbon Design
System. It looks like you might have a question about our work, so we wanted to
share a couple resources that you could use if you haven't tried them yet üôÇ.

If you're an IBMer, we have a couple of Slack channels available across all IBM
Workspaces:

- #carbon-design-system for questions about the Design System
- #carbon-components for questions about component styles
- #carbon-react for questions about our React components

If these resources don't work out, help us out by filling out a couple of
details below!

-->

## What package(s) are you using?

<!--
  Add an x in one of the options below, for example:
- [x] package name
-->

- [ ] `carbon-components`
- [x] `carbon-components-react`

## Summary
The current DataTable is suitable for situations where you can download the entire dataset and use the built-in sorting mechanism.
However, with large enough datasets, you must stream the data in a page at a time to prevent overloading either the client or the server.
This is incompatible with the current built-in sorting mechanism, because it only sorts the _page_.
It's preferable to simply retrieve the current sort state, i.e. 
```tsx
const [sortHeader, setSortHeader] = useState('created');
const [sortDirection, setSortDirection] = useState('None');

const [page, setPage] = useState(1);
const [pageSize, setPageSize] = useState(10);
const start = pageSize * (page - 1)
const end = start + pageSize
const { data } = useSWR([start, end, sortHeader, sortDirection, 'myDataset'], getDataset, {suspense: true});
<DataTable 
    onSortChanged={(key: string, direction: 'ASC' | 'DESC' | 'None') => setSortHeader(key); setSortDirection(direction)}
    ...
/>
```
However, it doesn't seem to be possible to do so.
A similar story applies to search.
What is the best way to scale the DataTable component so that its various functionality works well when populated by a backend that can perform its own search/sort/etc?
## Relevant information
For the early stages of my work, I intend to just retrieve the entire dataset since it is still small.
In the future, a feature may end up being requested that requires this functionality.
<!-- Provide as much useful information as you can -->

items.title: Allow to input pages in Pagination component
items.body:
Carbon Pagination currently allows user to go to previous or next page, but if user wants to jump to another page, an input field would be more flexible.


### Summary
Pagination is useful when putting data into table or lists, but select element from chromium supports up to only `10000` elements: https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/blink.git/+/master/Source/core/html/HTMLSelectElement.cpp#77. Presenting content with huge volume requires `jump to xxx page`.


Clarify if you are asking for design, development, or both design and
development.

### Justification

Chromium supports only `10000` elements: https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/blink.git/+/master/Source/core/html/HTMLSelectElement.cpp#77. If data volume is more than 10000 pages, user needs a better way to jump to specific page.

### Desired UX and success metrics

mockup: chromium supports up to only `10000` elements: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5575493/93842471-aaa83d80-fcc9-11ea-9aba-c4253938d273.png)

NA

items.title: Provide pagination bar heights to match new data table row heights

labels.name: severity: 3
labels.description: Affects minor functionality, has a workaround

items.body: ### Summary This is a request to add **at least one additional pagination bar height (32px)** to match the available row heights in order to avoid clashing heights. Currently there are 4 possible row heights for data tables: - Compact 24px - Short 32px - Default 48px - Tall 64px With Carbon 11 there will also be a 5th height (Medium 40px) - see https://github.com/carbon-design-system/carbon/issues/8369. However we only have one pagination bar height, meaning that for most row heights, the pagination bar will look out of sync. The difference is most jarring on short and compact row heights. We are asking for development support to add at least a 32px pagination bar height. Ideally we would have matching pagination and toolbar heights for any row height, but adding the 32px pagination bar is an excellent MVP. **As-Is** ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39408106/121440640-e9604f80-c94d-11eb-8460-f1fd525bc6d2.png) **Proposed** ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39408106/121440667-f3824e00-c94d-11eb-8693-c9482f39b46a.png) ### Justification We are rolling out the table settings feature more widely, which means that these alternative heights will begin to be more heavily used, making this visual inconsistency more obvious. Adding an additional pagination bar height will allow us to create visual harmony with minimal effort. ### Desired UX and success metrics When user switches to either a short (xs) or compact (sm) row height, the pagination bar would switch to a small height (32px). Same for data table toolbar - see related request [Provide data table toolbar heights to match new row heights #8875](https://github.com/carbon-design-system/carbon/issues/8875) ### "Must have" functionality Each of the pagination bar variations would have a 32px version. ### Specific timeline issues / requests Ideally it would be great to roll this out with Carbon 11 as we introduce the new row heights. We would love to roll this update into the data table settings feature being worked on by the Cloud & Cognitive data table workstream. ### Available extra resources We can provide design support and potentially some dev support.

items.title: DataTable: select all action is slow and block ui when the table has thousands of rows even with pagination
items.body:
### Summary
I use DataTable to list my data, because there may have lots of rows, so i implement pagination for this table. For example 6000 rows.  The select all action is slow and block ui for about 6 seconds. If there are 50000 rows of data, the section all action can crash my browser. However, the other actions like search, sort, pagination is fast.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19277713/83005243-23acc680-a043-11ea-8e97-03eeb4711129.png)
The wired thing is, select one by one is fast. 
And the cancel action is slow even there is only one selected and may crash browser if has more data.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19277713/83005734-c1a09100-a043-11ea-87a3-7c92931c4a38.png)

Here is my pagination code. If without the pagination, the select all can be slow too. I think the select all may need optimization inside the DataTable. 
```
<TableBody>
                  {rows
                    .slice((page - 1) * pageSize, page * pageSize)
                    .map(row => (
                      <TableRow key={row.id}>
                        <TableSelectRow {...getSelectionProps({ row })} />
                        {row.cells.map(cell => getCell(cell))}
                      </TableRow>
                    ))}
                </TableBody>

```
### Justification

This issue has effect on the user experience of our product.
